commits.message:
office-addin-dev-certs: add --domains option to install (#712)

This allows the set of domains to be customized if needed.

An example where customization is useful is if "localhost" is not allowed as a domain name. You use map a different name to the local port, but the SSL certificate needs to have that name listed.

For example, on Windows, the hosts file can map "dev-host" to 127.0.0.1 (IPv4) and ::1 (IPv6) by adding these lines to %systemroot%\system32\drivers\etc\hosts:

127.0.0.1 	dev-host
::1		dev-host

Then, use the --domains option to specify the IP addresses and host names:

office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1,::1,localhost,dev-host

Opening the browser to https://dev-host will show that the SSL certificate is valid.

pull_request.title: [minor] office-addin-dev-certs: add --domains option to install
pull_request.body:
This adds --domains as an option to the office-addin-dev-certs install command.

This allows the set of domains to be customized if needed. By default, the domains are "127.0.0.1" and "localhost".

An example where customization is useful is if "localhost" is not allowed as a domain name. You can map a different name to the local port, but the SSL certificate needs to have that name listed.

For example, on Windows, the hosts file can map "dev-host" to 127.0.0.1 (IPv4) and ::1 (IPv6) by adding these lines to %systemroot%\system32\drivers\etc\hosts:

127.0.0.1 	dev-host
::1		dev-host

Then, use the --domains option to specify the IP addresses and host names:

office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1,::1,localhost,dev-host

Opening the browser to https://dev-host will show that the SSL certificate is valid.


1. **Do these changes impact *command syntax* of any of the packages?** (e.g., add/remove command, add/remove a command parameter, or update required parameters)
Yes, 


2. **Do these changes impact *documentation*?** (e.g., a tutorial on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/overview/office-add-ins)
    If Yes, briefly describe what is impacted.


If you answered yes to any of these please do the following:
    > Include 'Rick-Kirkham' in the review
    > Make sure the README file is correct

**Validation/testing performed**:

1. I validated the default behavior of "office-addin-dev-certs install" is unchanged. 
2. I validated that with the --domains option added, the SSL certificate has those domains listed. 
    For example: office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1.::1,localhost,dev-host
3. I also validated the browser shows the url https://dev-host contains a valid SSL certificate and is trusted.

issue.title: console.log() for a Custom Function in Shared Runtime goes nowhere

labels.name: Needs: triage :mag:
labels.description: New issue, needs PM on rotation to triage ASAP

issue.body:
# Prerequisites

Please answer the following questions before submitting an issue. 
**YOU MAY DELETE THE PREREQUISITES SECTION.**
- I am running Node v16 (v18 doesn't work with the yo generator, I filed a ticket)
- I checked the documentation and found no answer (I have done everything and then some)
- I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed


# Expected behavior

If I put console.log() in a custom function it should log somewhere, like OfficeAddins.log.txt

Or in the debugger if I run from vscode


# Current behavior

There is no console.log() anywhere


## Steps to Reproduce

Try to get a console.log() of a custom function using a shared runtime from the yo generator project and it will not work.


## Context

Please provide any relevant information about your setup. This is important in case the issue is not reproducible except for under certain conditions.

* Operating System: Latest windows
* Node version: 16
* Office version: Latest
* Tool version: Latest

## Failure Logs

Please include any relevant log snippets, screenshots or code samples here.

```
11/12/2022 14:11:33	Verbose	CustomFunctions	[Execution] [Async] [Begin] Function=CONTOSO.FRENCHQUESTIONTWO, Workbook=Excel add-in 9f662e46-0311-4a4a-be5e-dbb7797a8b6c.xlsx		
11/12/2022 14:11:33	Unexpected	CustomFunctions	[Execution] [Async] [End] [Failure] Function=FRENCHQUESTIONTWO, Workbook=Excel add-in 9f662e46-0311-4a4a-be5e-dbb7797a8b6c.xlsx		
```

This is what in the output log, there is no console.log() appearing

Enable runtime logging and the log messages will go to the runtime log.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/testing/runtime-logging

commits.message:
VS Code launch.json no longer needs useWebView (#182)

Co-authored-by: Adam Krantz <adamk@microsoft.com>

pull_request.title: VS Code launch.json no longer needs useWebView
pull_request.body:
From https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/157587 I've learned that the useWebView is no longer needed for debugging with the Edge webview.

I validated that debugging an Excel task pane works even with this property removed.

1. **Do these changes impact any *npm scripts* commands (in package.json)?** (e.g., running 'npm run start')
No.

2. **Do these changes impact *VS Code debugging* options (launch.json)?**
Yes

3. **Do these changes impact *template output*?** (e.g., add/remove file, update file location, update file contents)
No.

4. **Do these changes impact *documentation*?** (e.g., a tutorial on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/overview/office-add-ins)
I don't think so.


If you answered yes to any of these please do the following:
    > Include 'Rick-Kirkham' in the review
    > Make sure the README file is correct

**Validation/testing performed**:

1. Opened the Office-Addin-TaskPane project in VS Code.
2. Ran the dev server.
3. Opened file excel.ts and set a breakpoint on line 25 which contains: range.load("address");
4. From Debug tab, selected "Excel Desktop (Edge Chromium)"
5. Click the play button to start debugging. 
6. When Excel opened, I clicked the ribbon button to open the task pane for the add-in, and clicked the Run button.
7. Hit the breakpoint.

issue.body:
Type: Bug The documentation about the launch config for Edge browser/webview debugging seems to be outdated. A warning is shown in launch.json that "type": "pwa-msedge" should be changed to "type": "msedge". However, when doing so, the "useWebView": "true" is no longer the correct syntax. issue.title: Custom-Functions-Metadata for multiple files?
issue.body:
It would be useful if multiple files could be provided as the input to generate one output metadata JSON.
There's two reasons I've come across why this would be useful
* To modularize the code a bit more. E.g., we have hundreds of functions and it gets a bit unruly having them all in one file.
* Functions coming from different places do not need to be combined in a separate step. E.g., we have some functions that generated by a script and some that a hand written, currently, an extra step is needed to merge them for the metadata generator.

Personally, I'm only worried about Webpack plugin, not the command line tool.

comment.body: The json generation should work if multiple files contain @customfunction in jsdoc comment.  You just need webpack config to include them in the functions.js bundle. Easiest way may be to import into functions.ts

commits.message:
office-addin-dev-certs: add --domains option to install (#712)

This allows the set of domains to be customized if needed.

An example where customization is useful is if "localhost" is not allowed as a domain name. You use map a different name to the local port, but the SSL certificate needs to have that name listed.

For example, on Windows, the hosts file can map "dev-host" to 127.0.0.1 (IPv4) and ::1 (IPv6) by adding these lines to %systemroot%\system32\drivers\etc\hosts:

127.0.0.1 	dev-host
::1		dev-host

Then, use the --domains option to specify the IP addresses and host names:

office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1,::1,localhost,dev-host

Opening the browser to https://dev-host will show that the SSL certificate is valid.

pull_request.title: [minor] office-addin-dev-certs: add --domains option to install
pull_request.body:
This adds --domains as an option to the office-addin-dev-certs install command.

This allows the set of domains to be customized if needed. By default, the domains are "127.0.0.1" and "localhost".

An example where customization is useful is if "localhost" is not allowed as a domain name. You can map a different name to the local port, but the SSL certificate needs to have that name listed.

For example, on Windows, the hosts file can map "dev-host" to 127.0.0.1 (IPv4) and ::1 (IPv6) by adding these lines to %systemroot%\system32\drivers\etc\hosts:

127.0.0.1 	dev-host
::1		dev-host

Then, use the --domains option to specify the IP addresses and host names:

office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1,::1,localhost,dev-host

Opening the browser to https://dev-host will show that the SSL certificate is valid.


1. **Do these changes impact *command syntax* of any of the packages?** (e.g., add/remove command, add/remove a command parameter, or update required parameters)
Yes, 


2. **Do these changes impact *documentation*?** (e.g., a tutorial on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/overview/office-add-ins)
    If Yes, briefly describe what is impacted.


If you answered yes to any of these please do the following:
    > Include 'Rick-Kirkham' in the review
    > Make sure the README file is correct

**Validation/testing performed**:

1. I validated the default behavior of "office-addin-dev-certs install" is unchanged. 
2. I validated that with the --domains option added, the SSL certificate has those domains listed. 
    For example: office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1.::1,localhost,dev-host
3. I also validated the browser shows the url https://dev-host contains a valid SSL certificate and is trusted.

issue.body:
# Prerequisites

Please answer the following questions before submitting an issue. 
**YOU MAY DELETE THE PREREQUISITES SECTION.**
- I am running Node v16 (v18 doesn't work with the yo generator, I filed a ticket)
- I checked the documentation and found no answer (I have done everything and then some)
- I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed


# Expected behavior

If I put console.log() in a custom function it should log somewhere, like OfficeAddins.log.txt

Or in the debugger if I run from vscode


# Current behavior

There is no console.log() anywhere


## Steps to Reproduce

Try to get a console.log() of a custom function using a shared runtime from the yo generator project and it will not work.


## Context

Please provide any relevant information about your setup. This is important in case the issue is not reproducible except for under certain conditions.

* Operating System: Latest windows
* Node version: 16
* Office version: Latest
* Tool version: Latest

## Failure Logs

Please include any relevant log snippets, screenshots or code samples here.

```

```

commits.message:
VS Code launch.json no longer needs useWebView (#182)

Co-authored-by: Adam Krantz <adamk@microsoft.com>

pull_request.title: VS Code launch.json no longer needs useWebView
pull_request.body:
From https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/157587 I've learned that the useWebView is no longer needed for debugging with the Edge webview.

I validated that debugging an Excel task pane works even with this property removed.

1. **Do these changes impact any *npm scripts* commands (in package.json)?** (e.g., running 'npm run start')
No.

2. **Do these changes impact *VS Code debugging* options (launch.json)?**
Yes

3. **Do these changes impact *template output*?** (e.g., add/remove file, update file location, update file contents)
No.

4. **Do these changes impact *documentation*?** (e.g., a tutorial on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/overview/office-add-ins)
I don't think so.


If you answered yes to any of these please do the following:
    > Include 'Rick-Kirkham' in the review
    > Make sure the README file is correct

**Validation/testing performed**:

1. Opened the Office-Addin-TaskPane project in VS Code.
2. Ran the dev server.
3. Opened file excel.ts and set a breakpoint on line 25 which contains: range.load("address");
4. From Debug tab, selected "Excel Desktop (Edge Chromium)"
5. Click the play button to start debugging. 
6. When Excel opened, I clicked the ribbon button to open the task pane for the add-in, and clicked the Run button.
7. Hit the breakpoint.

pull_request.title: VS Code launch.json no longer needs useWebView
pull_request.body:
From https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/157587 I've learned that the useWebView is no longer needed for debugging with the Edge webview.

I validated that debugging an Excel task pane works even with this property removed.

1. **Do these changes impact any *npm scripts* commands (in package.json)?** (e.g., running 'npm run start')
No.

2. **Do these changes impact *VS Code debugging* options (launch.json)?**
Yes

3. **Do these changes impact *template output*?** (e.g., add/remove file, update file location, update file contents)
No.

4. **Do these changes impact *documentation*?** (e.g., a tutorial on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/overview/office-add-ins)
I don't think so.


If you answered yes to any of these please do the following:
    > Include 'Rick-Kirkham' in the review
    > Make sure the README file is correct

**Validation/testing performed**:

1. Opened the Office-Addin-TaskPane project in VS Code.
2. Ran the dev server.
3. Opened file excel.ts and set a breakpoint on line 25 which contains: range.load("address");
4. From Debug tab, selected "Excel Desktop (Edge Chromium)"
5. Click the play button to start debugging. 
6. When Excel opened, I clicked the ribbon button to open the task pane for the add-in, and clicked the Run button.
7. Hit the breakpoint.

issue.title: Custom-Functions-Metadata for multiple files?
issue.body:
It would be useful if multiple files could be provided as the input to generate one output metadata JSON.
There's two reasons I've come across why this would be useful
* To modularize the code a bit more. E.g., we have hundreds of functions and it gets a bit unruly having them all in one file.
* Functions coming from different places do not need to be combined in a separate step. E.g., we have some functions that generated by a script and some that a hand written, currently, an extra step is needed to merge them for the metadata generator.

Personally, I'm only worried about Webpack plugin, not the command line tool.

comment.body: The json generation should work if multiple files contain @customfunction in jsdoc comment.  You just need webpack config to include them in the functions.js bundle. Easiest way may be to import into functions.ts

commits.message:
office-addin-dev-certs: add --domains option to install (#712)

This allows the set of domains to be customized if needed.

An example where customization is useful is if "localhost" is not allowed as a domain name. You use map a different name to the local port, but the SSL certificate needs to have that name listed.

For example, on Windows, the hosts file can map "dev-host" to 127.0.0.1 (IPv4) and ::1 (IPv6) by adding these lines to %systemroot%\system32\drivers\etc\hosts:

127.0.0.1 	dev-host
::1		dev-host

Then, use the --domains option to specify the IP addresses and host names:

office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1,::1,localhost,dev-host

Opening the browser to https://dev-host will show that the SSL certificate is valid.

pull_request.title: [minor] office-addin-dev-certs: add --domains option to install
pull_request.body:
This adds --domains as an option to the office-addin-dev-certs install command.

This allows the set of domains to be customized if needed. By default, the domains are "127.0.0.1" and "localhost".

An example where customization is useful is if "localhost" is not allowed as a domain name. You can map a different name to the local port, but the SSL certificate needs to have that name listed.

For example, on Windows, the hosts file can map "dev-host" to 127.0.0.1 (IPv4) and ::1 (IPv6) by adding these lines to %systemroot%\system32\drivers\etc\hosts:

127.0.0.1 	dev-host
::1		dev-host

Then, use the --domains option to specify the IP addresses and host names:

office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1,::1,localhost,dev-host

Opening the browser to https://dev-host will show that the SSL certificate is valid.


1. **Do these changes impact *command syntax* of any of the packages?** (e.g., add/remove command, add/remove a command parameter, or update required parameters)
Yes, 


2. **Do these changes impact *documentation*?** (e.g., a tutorial on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/overview/office-add-ins)
    If Yes, briefly describe what is impacted.


If you answered yes to any of these please do the following:
    > Include 'Rick-Kirkham' in the review
    > Make sure the README file is correct

**Validation/testing performed**:

1. I validated the default behavior of "office-addin-dev-certs install" is unchanged. 
2. I validated that with the --domains option added, the SSL certificate has those domains listed. 
    For example: office-addin-dev-certs install --domains 127.0.0.1.::1,localhost,dev-host
3. I also validated the browser shows the url https://dev-host contains a valid SSL certificate and is trusted.

issue.title: console.log() for a Custom Function in Shared Runtime goes nowhere

labels.name: Needs: triage :mag:
labels.description: New issue, needs PM on rotation to triage ASAP

issue.body:
# Prerequisites

Please answer the following questions before submitting an issue. 
**YOU MAY DELETE THE PREREQUISITES SECTION.**
- I am running Node v16 (v18 doesn't work with the yo generator, I filed a ticket)
- I checked the documentation and found no answer (I have done everything and then some)
- I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed


# Expected behavior

If I put console.log() in a custom function it should log somewhere, like OfficeAddins.log.txt

Or in the debugger if I run from vscode


# Current behavior

There is no console.log() anywhere


## Steps to Reproduce

Try to get a console.log() of a custom function using a shared runtime from the yo generator project and it will not work.


## Context

Please provide any relevant information about your setup. This is important in case the issue is not reproducible except for under certain conditions.

* Operating System: Latest windows
* Node version: 16
* Office version: Latest
* Tool version: Latest

## Failure Logs

Please include any relevant log snippets, screenshots or code samples here.

pull_request.title: VS Code launch.json no longer needs useWebView
pull_request.body:
From https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/157587 I've learned that the useWebView is no longer needed for debugging with the Edge webview.

I validated that debugging an Excel task pane works even with this property removed.

1. **Do these changes impact any *npm scripts* commands (in package.json)?** (e.g., running 'npm run start')
No.

2. **Do these changes impact *VS Code debugging* options (launch.json)?**
Yes

3. **Do these changes impact *template output*?** (e.g., add/remove file, update file location, update file contents)
No.

4. **Do these changes impact *documentation*?** (e.g., a tutorial on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/overview/office-add-ins)
I don't think so.


If you answered yes to any of these please do the following:
    > Include 'Rick-Kirkham' in the review
    > Make sure the README file is correct

**Validation/testing performed**:

1. Opened the Office-Addin-TaskPane project in VS Code.
2. Ran the dev server.
3. Opened file excel.ts and set a breakpoint on line 25 which contains: range.load("address");
4. From Debug tab, selected "Excel Desktop (Edge Chromium)"
5. Click the play button to start debugging. 
6. When Excel opened, I clicked the ribbon button to open the task pane for the add-in, and clicked the Run button.
7. Hit the breakpoint.

issue.title: Custom-Functions-Metadata for multiple files?
issue.body:
It would be useful if multiple files could be provided as the input to generate one output metadata JSON.
There's two reasons I've come across why this would be useful
* To modularize the code a bit more. E.g., we have hundreds of functions and it gets a bit unruly having them all in one file.
* Functions coming from different places do not need to be combined in a separate step. E.g., we have some functions that generated by a script and some that a hand written, currently, an extra step is needed to merge them for the metadata generator.

Personally, I'm only worried about Webpack plugin, not the command line tool.

comment.body: The json generation should work if multiple files contain @customfunction in jsdoc comment.  You just need webpack config to include them in the functions.js bundle. Easiest way may be to import into functions.ts
